												I grew up playing the Nintendo version of Bionic Commando (there was an arcade version too) and loved the game enough to still play it to completion every year. It was the first game that had a swear and a gruesome scene of someone's head blowing up. For those that haven't played or heard of Bionic Commando, its a 2D gunning platformer with a world map and different, unique and vibrant levels with a wide variety of enemies. If you think you've done every 2D platformer before, have you tried a platformer with no jump button? This game really hangs its hat on the fact that you use a bionic arm for platform traversal. The arm is pretty versatile, the normal arm button launches it diagonally, when you use a direction and the arm it will blast out forward, and ducking while using the arm will send it forward, but lower. You can use the arm upward too. With the arm you can swing and climb. You can release the arm's grasp to drop and release the swing. In this version of the game you can grapple barrels, pick them up and throw them. Its a nice touch. You can also use your arm to counter bullets. Its a nice feature.With the overhead map you and your helicopter pilot will fly around to different areas / levels. There are two types of areas. Combat zones and neutral zones where you'll talk with people, obtain items that will help you and club a prisoner with your bionic arm. The combat zones have been modernized while still giving them a vibrant, colorful feel that makes it feel like a game in a good way. The excellent old chip tunes have been modernized and they all sound good, but personally, I prefer the older tunes.The combat areas have a two or three sections, usually broken up with a communication room that will further the story for you and open doors to the next segment of the area. So an outside area will go indoors, a towering spire will reveal the upper half of the spire when you use the communication room. You can also wire tap in the communication room and new to this version of Bionic Commando is a simple mini game that has you hurling a yellow ball in a three dimensional box. If the ball exits the box, then you fail, but there's no consequence for failing like the Nintendo classic where enemies would flood the room. The goal is to rotate the box and hurtle the ball to yellow blocks that will prevent the ball from going out of bounds. Its pretty easy and it breaks up the game. Its just extra icing on the cake. The game also has communication chips like the old game, so in certain areas you'll need to have the blue chip to communicate. The Nintendo version of the game had you pick a weapon, a communication chip and an item when entering each level. Thankfully this version lets you use all of your chips, which will spare you some time.As for the weapons, to be honest, its a little underwhelming. You have your standard 2 bullets on screen revolver, a weak laser, a short range shotgun, a rocket launcher and a bouncing laser that shoots at an angle. The angled laser can shoot enemies hiding behind cover or above you, but since the game gives you so many other ways to kill covered enemies it seems useless.. The original Nintendo game had a 3 way gun that felt useful and the original rocket launcher would plow through enemies. Now there seems to be an emphasis on realism where the explosion of the rocket launcher will damage if not kill you. The rockets also wave, giving it a chance to miss. The shotgun does the same damage as two bullets from your revolver. The weapons just feel useless when compared to the simple starting revolver. You'll be able to change your weapons on the fly with the shoulder buttons, which again is a welcome tweak to gameplay from the Nintendo version forcing you to be stuck with one weapon the entire level. The most useful weapon not in the Nintendo version is a simple grenade. So you use 3 buttons, arm, gun and grenade throw. Its a good way to kill enemies behind cover.On the map, your helicopter moves along lines level to level, giving you choice of where to go. The only catch is that convoys patrol these lines and if you run into one, you'll fight in a top down stage. Its nice combat diversity that doesn't last long. You can use your arm to whip away bullets, but each of these areas is over quickly. You can find easy lives this way.One of the biggest changes from the Nintendo to the Rearmed version is 2 player co-op through the levels and also multi-player death match mode. They feel like good add ons, but for those that like the single player, the biggest change are the bosses. The original Nintendo bosses were more like enemy rooms with a core at the center. Now the bosses are giant machines for the most part. These machines take a good chunk of time to destroy, have different patterns and phases of the boss fight. Its a really nice change to the original. Plus, the bosses have some character and brief dialog before each fight. It adds a lot of charm to the game.As for challenge, the game is easier than the Nintendo version. You can take more damage, you have more attacks and can use multiple items at once. There is no real consequence to the game like there was on Nintendo. There are unlimited continues, using all of your lives merely sends you to the map. The game feels easier and you can take more bullets before you die.In later areas when using the arm on horizontally moving platforms, the arm is suddenly very flawed. It will let go quickly if the platform you are on is moving. Sometimes, climbing onto a moving platform will nudge you off the back of it. You can even run against the movement where suddenly you're running in place when the platform is moving to the left and you are running to the right. Or trying to drop off platforms will sometimes bump you back onto them. Toward the end of the game it turns into a fight against the game's mechanic on top of what can already be a forgiving arm hit detection that doesn't always grab onto things. A lot of the time the arm will grab onto something as its retracting. The Nintendo version had that flaw too, but it wasn't nearly as abundant as in Rearmed.For children of the 80s this was a difficult game on Nintendo, but now it might run you 4 hours to complete. There are a few difficulties to chose from too. I can say that $2.50 is a good price for the game, but I have difficulty justifying $10 for a game this old that is really just a fresh coat of paint with some memorable bosses. The levels are quick and don't offer much challenge to veterans who have already completed the game 20+ years ago. There are a few new levels including the final level that feels excessively long. There are plenty of challenge rooms inside non combat zones where you're forced to get from point A to point B, but that's hardly an attraction. The game has in game medals, but no Steam achievements. After everything being said, I prefer the original and I think that the sequel to this remake is a better game, mostly because I felt like I hadn't already played it.

												I came here with the purpose of finding a game I didn't like and seeing if it was worth a negative review.Glad I came back to this one.  As it turns out, its a rough diamond.Its a jarring game to play initially.  We are so used to knowing what a shooter is and what a platformer is.  When a game like Bionic Commando denies us a jump button then it becomes very stressful.  My advice is do the tutorials and attempt the challenge rooms within the friendly zones first.They will teach you the mechanics and you will quickly be able to move fluidly the way you want to and be a true bionic commando, instead of a slow clunky frustrated commando wondering what you are doing.The swing mechanics of the bionic arm are very fun once you take a few minutes to get used to them, and you will be taking on platforms and bad guys with ease quickly.  You won't even mind not having a jump button after you've figured it all out.Level progression is a bit different too.  Area 0 is a friendly zone that must be entered to find the tutorial, and Area 1 must be entered to find the challenge rooms that put into practice more of the advanced skills.You won't initially know where to go, but by exploring the areas you can access you will eventually build up a handy arsenal of equipment and knowledge of the game.   I highly recommend exploring all the friendly zone to start with and entering the rooms to collect useful equipment as well as getting used to moving around outside of combat.  After you've comfortably explored the friendly areas and rooms, tackle the nearby accessable low numbered areas and dominate those enemies in combat.As an example of a time where you will be initially confused, you need to explore a friendly zone to get the flares you need to more easily explore Area 4.  The level can still possibly be completed, but you will get frustrated wondering why an early level has you zipping about blind trying to find a random platform or bit of wall you need to succeed.  Turns out exploration of a friendly zone was the answer and only one I discovered by accident after getting frustrated and quitting out to try another stage.Bosses are in every enemy stage, and there is a great mechanic where you can hack enemy consoles for a chance of learning the boss weakness.  I found the early bosses to be easy enough that I didn't get frustrated and wanted to keep playing.  Beating bosses earns you more gear as well as more levels to play with so its a rewarding experience.There are also enemy trucks zipping about the world map also give you a chance to play a different kind of shooting game and experiment with weapons.  Its a bit repetitive, but a fun distraction between the main game.In conclusion, Bionic Commando Rearmed is definitely a game that tries something different and succeeds.  If you can cope with it being different, put in that half an hour to learn how to play the game.  There is a real treat lying ahead for you.EDIT: I'll admit later levels and challenges do become frustrating so just enjoy the fun bits.

												Absolutely spectacular remake of one of the most iconic games from my childhood. Bionic Commando was one of the very best games for NES, and remains a very fun game to this day. This remake is a faithful rendition of the old classic with updated graphics.I was wary when I first got this game, afraid they may have added new controls to make full use of an XBox controller. But that apprehension went out the window as soon as I started playing. The graphics look beautiful, I was stunned to see how good this old game looks with new visuals, and I was amazed to find they kept the old control scheme: D-pad (or left joystick) and just two buttons (A and B). To any of you who might be thinking "wow, just two buttons, OMG WTF???" you're missing the point of this game. It's old-school platforming fun, with a really good plot and great challenges that really make you think. This is the kind of game I want my kids to play (whenever I have them in a few years). The mechanics are a bit frustrating at times, since there is no "jump" button, no "run" button, or any of the other frills you would find in most third-person shooters. Instead, you have just two buttons: one to shoot your gun, and another to shoot your bionic arm, which functions basically like a grappling hook. You can shoot the grappling hook in exactly 5 directions: straight left, straight right, 45 degrees up-left, 45 degrees up-right, and straight up. Though this might seem like a limitation, it's actually an integral part of what gives this game its challenge and creativity. Back in the day when this was programmed for NES, it was the pinnacle of gaming, and today, it's a wonderful challenge that gets better and better as you play longer and get used to the controls. The reason I want my future kids to play this kind of game is that it really forces you to think outside the box. For example, there are some areas that seem impassable, but with a bit of thought, you can jump off the platform, turn back and catch onto it, then swing past and catch another platform with a little bit of timing. Things like that are what makes Bionic Commando something unique in the world of gaming, teaching kids (or nostalgic adults) how to think outside the box and work with what you have to overcome challenges. As I mentioned before, the graphics look great. It's not absolutely stunning, definitely not on par with Skyrim or The Witcher 3, but still very good. If you played the NES classic like me, then you will be absolutely blown away, but for people who are new to Bionic Commando, it probably won't stun you. There's nothing wrong with the graphics, it's just obvious that it's a minimalistic platformer. The tutorial reminds me of Frozen Synapse, while the main game looks similar to Valdis Story: An Abyssal City, but less cartoony. Speaking of the tutorial, you really should play it when you get to it. If you haven't played Bionic Commando before, you'll need the time to get used to the controls, and if you have, you could probably use a refresher course, especially since you'll be using an XBox controller instead of the NES controller. Please, for the love of God, don't try to play this game with your keyboard. For one thing, I don't think you can get a true feel for the game without using a real D-pad and real A & B buttons, and for another, some of the reviews have stated that in later levels the key binding is messed up which is very problematic when you're facing a Boss Battle where one false move could spell your doom. I'm actually seriously considering getting a USB NES controller specifically for this game, but it works great with an XBox controller so there's no need for that unless you're just nostalgic.Sound quality is excellent, I think it does a great job of staying true to the classic sounds while updating them to the modern era. The music sounds like a revamped version of the original soundtrack, and the sound effects are a perfect blend of just enough chiptunes to make it feel older, while still maintaining a level of modern quality. Overall, this is a spectacular game that I would recommend to anyone who is a fan of platformers or looking to try one. With various difficulty levels to choose from, it has great replay value, and it's simple to learn but difficult to master. $10 isn't that much for a game these days, and Bionic Commando goes on sale pretty regularly so I'd say it's definitely worth every penny. Oh, who am I kidding? I can't try to write an unbiased review of Bionic Commando: Rearmed, this is a faithful remake of one of the first video games I ever played. It's awesome because I said so, now buy it and love it. --------------------------------------------------------------------If you enjoy my reviews, why not follow my curation page? 												One thing I suspect divides reviewers of this game is whether they remember the original Bionic Commando - if you do, that will set your expectations accordingly and you will go in expecting a platform game with solid weapons where the main fun is in the experience of using/swinging around on the arm, and yes, slightly repetitive gameplay at times. If that is what you are going in for, this game hits the spot perfectly If that is *not* what you're expecting, though, it could feel like something of a let-down, because while it starts out looking like a fairly story-driven FPS, runs through the standard Super Soldier stuff like Metal Gear Solid/Rambo/Deus Ex/Commando etc. (you are the ultimate warrior of bygone days, called upong to reluctantly return to service and save the day), it really is just a platformer. I think this could cause some to take a dim view of the game, which is understandable. Anyway, the whole thing is better than I was led to believe, and is a solidly implemented nod to something *like* the original in 3D. Swing, kill, get out of the line of fire, kill, swing, get a better gun, swing, kill - like spiderman with guns, as a platform game. Swinging on the arm is done brilliantly, guns work well and you get upgrades regularly (one at a time like the original game, some would have liked to see a pack full of weapons to switch between but in fairness that might not make sense given the character). Boss battles are well done, satisfying and interesting without any of the tedium and brokenness that seems to plague many games' boss battles. There is one possible exception on the boss battles thing, but a) it is spoilerish and b) doesn't ruin the game. Overall, this platformer scores well. Before you play, watch some videos of the original 2D game and see what you are signing up for - and if you decide to go in knowing that Splinter Cell it ain't, this game is good, solid, old-fashioned fun. Overall, graphics aren't particularly fabulous, it's a (fairly) repetitive platformer, and nostalgia would not have carried it alone, but it scores an 8/10 from me for one reason, something that is missing so often from games: Playability

												Bionic Commando was a decent enough arcade action game, when it debuted in 1987. Cartoonish, tricky, demanding, full of genuinely vexing little obstacles here and there. Its NES port, technically a sequel to the arcade game, remains the gold standard "home version that clobbered its arcade counterpart" in my book, adding many more stages, many more enemies and obstacles, and some genuinely hair-bristling cruel and unforgiving claw-swinging physics challenges that made you feel really accomplished when you finally cleared them. Bionic Commando was the first NES game I finished, partly due to being a very late arrival to the NES world, but partly also because it was the first game I owned to seem, frankly, as though its unfolding story justified the work involved. I felt like I'd really accomplished something, the day I finally arrived at that endscreen with Joe's signature.Rarely does lightning strike twice, in the way it did with Bionic Commando Rearmed. This is a really excellent remake and update of the NES version of the game. Everything you loved about the original is still present, with a significantly updated weapons arsenal (each with a collectible power-up elsewhere in the game), an entire system of "challenge rooms" offering difficult, timed obstacle courses to hone your skills with the arm, and, thanks to the greater room afforded for text and dialogue, a richer and more vivid telling of the story, affording better lines to the supporting cast, and a better sense of pace to the story told. The shift from 8-bit "physics" to 2.5D simulated physics is surprisingly welcome. Getting used to the weight and flow of motion in Rearmed's world took less time than I feared, and as I reached later stages that my thumbs remembered intimately on the NES, I found the timing familiar enough for my "twitch memory" to be useful. The life bar is markedly more forgiving than the NES' "acquire life dots as you go" approach, and touching an enemy no longer results in a loss of life in itself, making it easier to climb onto some of those tricky, cramped ledges with an enemy soldier. There are some genuinely innovative uses of the tools at hand in BCR that weren't present in the original, too -- try firing the shotgun while hanging from the claw, for example, or firing the claw at an enemy combatant for a brief, if grim, human shield. The stages have never looked so beautiful, and it's easier to understand their purpose, and the nature of the structures you're traveling through, in Rearmed. I even recognized the areas traveled in the original Bionic Commando arcade game, thanks to the higher-quality visuals, and was able to understand pieces of Joe's original mission from the things learned about those stages in Rearmed. Some of the goofier adversaries of the original game gain renewed clarity with the visual facelift, and become less adorable, more plausible. Fear not, though. Many of the goofy classic enemies are just as goofy as ever, some even more so.The connecting arc from Commando to Bionic Commando, through Bionic Commando (NES) into Rearmed is stronger than ever. The overhead combat stages when encountering an enemy during transfer on the map screen has never been quite so beautiful, with multiple terrains, classic overhead action, and includes a new song on the soundtrack, "Meet The Enemy And Descend," that ties this game firmly back to Commando. (Listen carefully, and you'll recognize the chord progression of the Hubbard version of the Commando theme ever before the SID warbles accompany the analog monophonic synth bass.) The soundtrack is quite nice, too. Pleasantly retro-squelchy without being preciously nostalgic, it thumps, sirens, howls and buzzes through the quite excellent NES melodies. "Advance With Caution," the game's main theme, remains my favorite of the tracks so far, with its glitchy, bitcrushed lead synth and occasional wide portamento sweeps, though its exhilarating pre-dawn SpecOps maneuver sibling, "Heat Wave," brims with the sort of potential energy I'd come to love from Jan Hammer's Miami Vice soundtrack work. If you're not deep into the game's mindset and stepping quietly with sidearm at the ready by the time "Killt's Hidden Treasures" plays, maybe this game just isn't for you.The NES original was as nonlinear as it could be, given its system limitations, but thanks to the unlimited continue system and open endgame with all levels unlocked for unlimited replay, Bionic Commando Rearmed really encourages the players who've toughed it out and won to go back and try again, with new gear, new tricks, new experience. Speedruns, no-gun runs, creep-and-take-'em-all-out-unseen stealth runs, don't-touch-the-floor runs, difficult weapon runs, find-every-nook-and-cranny runs...this game really encourages you to replay its levels and explore it thoroughly. The weapons arsenal can be used to tremendous advantage; I found myself revisiting guns I'd dismissed as "useless," and discovering ways to really get the most out of them. (A master with the vector gun can do *amazing* things with it...) I'm seldom inspired to replay games I've completed, but I find myself returning to Rearmed, again and again.My only real complaints have been that it's a bit short -- I would love to see Rearmed 2's levels released as a DLC pack, but they're currently a console exclusive -- and even with the relearning curve, I breezed through it, my first time, in under two  hours. That was a very respectable game duration for 1988, but by 2008, it seemed a bit short, a bit wanting for expansion, for later missions. I doubt it's going to see much new love, as it's an older title now, but nonetheless, that's really the only thing I found myself wanting for, in it. In fairness, though, I really did love the 1988 NES version, and I wanted this to be a very faithful, but slightly tweaked and improved, version of it. It is -- and if that appeals to you as it appealed to me, you're going to love Rearmed. If you're hoping for a dramatic update, it is, but if you're hoping for a dramatic departure, look elsewhere. This was, in my admittedly biased opinion, an attempt to revive the best damned platformer of the NES, and Grin seems to have treated its source material with all the reverence I would have wanted them to apply to such a legendary game.This isn't for everyone: it's a very faithful recreation of a singularly unique NES game. But it is very much what it sets out to be, and that's a thing of real beauty in this day and age of weaksauce nostalgic property reboots. The only game like it that I've encountered was the remastered edition of Ducktales, a similarly brilliant and reverent resurrection of a past classic.If you're been waiting to see the Albatross fly again...well, your number's up, monster. ;)

Summary/Overview Bionic Commando is a rated Mature run-and-gun side-scrolling platformer very similar to Contra. The primary characteristic alike in both of these games is the ability only to swing from area to area instead of including a button to jump. I know that many children and teenagers growing up won’t be able to appreciate this remake of the classic Nintendo Entertainment System game because it already seems to hard without a jump button. I do realize wholeheartedly the stigma that would ♥♥♥♥ modern-day gamers off. I understand you, but I assure you if you have some time, patience and practice, then you will get good at this game and succeed. One of the main hallmarks in the Contra and the Bionic Commando series is action-packed run-and-gun gameplay that shows no mercy toward enemies.Original release: Nintendo Entertainment System in 1988, Game Boy in 1992Newly updated release Bionic Commando Rearmed: August 14, 2008, PC release, also released on PlayStation Network and Xbox LivePublisher, Developer: CapcomGenre: action, side-scrolling, platformer Presentation     The graphics have been updated from the original Nintendo Entertainment System counter-part. They are now more crisp, show improved lighting and have a better enemy, environment animations. The story is presented through communication hubs that tell you more about the story as you progress through the levels. The story is the classic hallmark of many real-life warzone tales and stories of today.Gameplay     The primary characteristic that sets Bionic Commando and Contra apart from many platformers now is that they can be played in a variety of ways. If you are really good already at the game, you can choose to speedrun while skipping the story and many enemies. You don’t always have to take on every single enemy; this is all up to you based on how much health you currently have and how well you trust in your skills. Unlike some platformers that require only button pressing to be successful, Bionic Commando requires you to know enemy patterns precisely; Capcom did this within the original Mega Man games as well. If your movement is even the slightest bit unprecise, you are going to have to replay levels again and again until you clear them.      In fact, I remember watching some gamers on the REACT YouTube channel play the original Contra on the original Nintendo and they struggled. The difference there was that Contra allowed for extra continues. However, Bionic Commando Rearmed does not have that feature. Either you occasionally gain extra lives from level to level and refill more health by defeating random enemies, or you have one life to make the most of it.Does Bionic Commando Rearmed Appeal to the Modern-Age Gamers in the Digital Generation?     Yes, and no. If you are a modern-day gamer that wants a trip back through nostalgia and have never played the old-school side-scrolling hard platformers that were around back then, this will give you a first-person test-drive through all those years, in the late 1980’s through early 1990’s. However, if you are like me and don’t have as much time as you used to right now to play games and not enough patience or time before moving on to other games in your backlog, then I would not recommend it. However, if you don’t have a fairly large backlog and want something to play for a long while, constantly improving and transitioning between all the difficulties from easy to hard.Controls     You use basic mechanics on the keyboard while using the arrow keys also to control your release of your bionic arm. You need precise aim to be able to swing and pull yourself up to other platforms. This is the hallmark of these original side-scrolling games like this. The controls work ok for keyboard and mouse, but I know I am not alone when I say that the original experience is much better through using a controller. It would be awesome if there could be PC compatibility for a Nintendo Entertainment System controller.Positive, Negative AspectsPros•Awesome 8-bit soundtrack that is high action•Awesome main character model that has been updated from the original. The main character looks cooler than he did before•Enemy models are represented based on their colors by faction•It is fun to run-and-gun and shoot enemies that we need to kill for a purpose•Excellent objectives, goals and milestones to work towardsCons•Might not appeal to the current generation of gamers we currently have•Takes much time and patience since there is also one initial life without any continues in single-player•More variety of controller options would be a nice addition for Capcom to add eventually•Capcom, give us a remastered version of the 2008 more current generation version to go along with this oneOverall- 7/10     A good remake of a classic side-scrolling platformer that takes strategy, time and patience to master.Key1-3 = poor4-5 = ok6-7 = good8-10 = amazingDisclaimer     This game was provided by Accidently Reviewed. A remake of the classic NES title that seems to stay very true to its core gameplay mechanics whilst also adding other content.Plays fine on a keyboard but a controller would probably be more recommended whatwith it being a platformer. The controller input isn't rebindable and there are preset control types the game allows you to use but the controls themselves should be relatively simple enough to play through with.Difficulties range from Easy, Medium, and Hard. From what I see Hard mode on this game overall makes it a bit harder than the NES Bionic Commando with its high number, damage resisting, beefed up enemy count and Spencer being able to sustain fewer damage.As it goes like with the NES one there are two kinds of gameplay, its core platforming sections which is basically 90% of the game and the occassional top-down shooter sections. The top-down shooter sections are as occassional as before. When trying to select an stage you do so from a somewhat visually appalling-in-comparison mapscreen where you're a helicopter hovering over a numbered Area to descend to. The top-down shooter sections will only come up likely by chance because you happen to be trying to select an area to descend to from the overhead map and and an enemy truck on the map happens to come your way. It's still as basic as ever; top-down perspective, shoot anything that shoots back with its extremely simplistic controls (with the new addition of the movement via the analog stick) and style like with any other game of its kind. The usual end-goal exit has been replaced with a non-retaliating obstruction that you have to destroy. You can breeze right through these sections with little to no trouble especially if you've acquired a strong enough weapon or two. Used to be that the only good reason to do these top-down shooter parts is to collect obtainable Continues from specific enemies. This time around they're unlimited so there's no real good reason to actually make a forward attempt to go do these anymore although lives are still a thing but I'm not entirely sure if you can farm those properly. You get 2 (or 3, I forget) lives by default. As tradition would go doing a proper job at staying alive and completing a level won't result in much inconveniences with starting a level over at a point especially if all lives have been wasted.Most of the mechanics & features in the NES version have made it here and work pretty much the same way, like the bionic arm still being able to block bullets if the action's performed right and only being able to respawn from the beginning of the stage & most doorways, specifically & especially the ones that enable access to boss doors.Its core mechanic is the replacement of a jump button/option to a bionic arm that allows you to grapple in 5 directions (←, ↖, ↑, ↗ →) onto platforms for either climbing or swinging likely consistently in succession. Learning bionic arm platforming may take a bit of time to learn fully and get used to but I thought it was pretty worth it when put to proper use. There are even some tutorial and challenge levels to help get a better handle with it.At least on Medium difficulty and later, there are no longer any enemies that die in one hit with weaker weapons. You also have a health bar now as opposed to the squares that indicate how many hits you can take from anything. This also means that there are no longer any collectible "bullets" to pick up from killed enemies as the bullets have been replaced by obtainable Score Tokens and random health refills.A few items and weapons from the NES one have been replaced by many newer ones (weapons mostly) that are actually all very useful in the right situation as I never actually found myself picking favorites. Every item & weapon you acquire are now all automatically equipped with the ability to switch weapons in-game. You can find upgrades for each weapon however you'd have to put in effort into locating them as they're pretty much all hidden in secret areas. Practically all of the notable parts of every stage in this game are kept the way they are with some changes made for better or worse like complete scenery/atmosphere overhauls and other additions to prolong the stages a bit maybe. A few bosses have been replaced with more new ones to add variety in these fights one way or another they've been redesigned. In the later half of the game you'll have to fight most of them again in their upgraded forms. Plus, you actually have to fight them now because the choice to skip a fight altogether has been removed. The final boss fight too has been completely redone and now has his own incredibly long specific stage with the final escape still mostly being the way it is as it was.It's just a personal issue but I didn't find the visuals & graphics & whatever the like to be all too appropriate with the gameplay but all-in-all I enjoyed it and thought that it pretty much played almost exactly and then some like the NES title.

												I'll start this review by simply saying that Bionic Commando Rearmed is the best platformer game on Steam, hands down.BCR was developed by a swedish studio called GRIN, they had previously made the Ghost Recon: Advanced Warfighter games which were "okay".But in 2008 they really hit the motherload with this one, the game is an HD remake of the original NES game "Bionic Commando" and not does it only add more content to the mix, but even refines the original experience making it a superior version to the classic.In BCR you play as Nathan Spencer, a "Bionic Commando" with a giant robotic arm that operates as a telescopic grappling hook you can launch in five different directions, making it perfect for flinging around like Spider-Man. (Or Tarzan, but let's face it, nobody thinks Tarzan is cool anymore.)But there is a twist! You cant jump, the reason for this was originally the fact that the NES controller only had the A + B buttons which most games used for different actions. Shooting took the other button and grappling hook the other, meaning there werent enough buttons for jumping.For this reason, the developers had to get the level design absolutely perfect for the game to work, and oh boy did they succeed. The level design in Bionic Commando is still one of the best in any platformer game still to this day.What about the music? Well simply put it's AMAZING, after finishing the game twice i dont think there is a single bad track in the entire OST of the game. Even the originals from the NES game sound amazing, but they really did the remastering well in this one.If i'd have to give the game some criticism, (which is really hard btw) it would probably be the PC porting. While it certainly is superior to the other versions in terms of graphical fidelity, rebindable keys and proper sound settings, it's lacking an option for enabling vsync.This doesn't sound so bad at first, but when you realize that your rig is capable of running the game in ludicrous speed (I had about 400-470 FPS during the entire game) it can cause serious issues with overheating in your GPU.All in all, BCR is one helluva masterpiece of platformers and one of the brightest moments in Crapcom's history, if they only had hired these guys to remake the old Mega Man games...The game sells for 8,99€ on Steam and for that price i can certainly recommend you buying it. The game offers about eight hours of gameplay, but that number might vary depending on how much you have played platformers before or if you wish to complete the challenge missions. It should also be noted that the game is a remake of something that was on NES, so the replay value is pretty much endless.Lastly, GRIN was shut down in 2009 after their commercial failure with the new Bionic Commando game, (I'll talk about that a bit later) and because they had multiple projects going on at the same time, even though publishers were delaying their payments.Most of the GRIN development team went ahead to start a new development studio called "Overkill Software", sounds familiar? Yeah, these are the same guys who made the Payday games.One last thing, the last boss of this game is Adolf Hitler, yeah.

Summary/Overview Bionic Commando is a rated Mature run-and-gun side-scrolling platformer very similar to Contra. The primary characteristic alike in both of these games is the ability only to swing from area to area instead of including a button to jump. I know that many children and teenagers growing up won’t be able to appreciate this remake of the classic Nintendo Entertainment System game because it already seems to hard without a jump button. I do realize wholeheartedly the stigma that would ♥♥♥♥ modern-day gamers off. I understand you, but I assure you if you have some time, patience and practice, then you will get good at this game and succeed. One of the main hallmarks in the Contra and the Bionic Commando series is action-packed run-and-gun gameplay that shows no mercy toward enemies.Original release: Nintendo Entertainment System in 1988, Game Boy in 1992Newly updated release Bionic Commando Rearmed: August 14, 2008, PC release, also released on PlayStation Network and Xbox LivePublisher, Developer: CapcomGenre: action, side-scrolling, platformer Presentation     The graphics have been updated from the original Nintendo Entertainment System counter-part. They are now more crisp, show improved lighting and have a better enemy, environment animations. The story is presented through communication hubs that tell you more about the story as you progress through the levels. The story is the classic hallmark of many real-life warzone tales and stories of today.Gameplay     The primary characteristic that sets Bionic Commando and Contra apart from many platformers now is that they can be played in a variety of ways. If you are really good already at the game, you can choose to speedrun while skipping the story and many enemies. You don’t always have to take on every single enemy; this is all up to you based on how much health you currently have and how well you trust in your skills. Unlike some platformers that require only button pressing to be successful, Bionic Commando requires you to know enemy patterns precisely; Capcom did this within the original Mega Man games as well. If your movement is even the slightest bit unprecise, you are going to have to replay levels again and again until you clear them.      In fact, I remember watching some gamers on the REACT YouTube channel play the original Contra on the original Nintendo and they struggled. The difference there was that Contra allowed for extra continues. However, Bionic Commando Rearmed does not have that feature. Either you occasionally gain extra lives from level to level and refill more health by defeating random enemies, or you have one life to make the most of it.Does Bionic Commando Rearmed Appeal to the Modern-Age Gamers in the Digital Generation?     Yes, and no. If you are a modern-day gamer that wants a trip back through nostalgia and have never played the old-school side-scrolling hard platformers that were around back then, this will give you a first-person test-drive through all those years, in the late 1980’s through early 1990’s. However, if you are like me and don’t have as much time as you used to right now to play games and not enough patience or time before moving on to other games in your backlog, then I would not recommend it. However, if you don’t have a fairly large backlog and want something to play for a long while, constantly improving and transitioning between all the difficulties from easy to hard.Controls     You use basic mechanics on the keyboard while using the arrow keys also to control your release of your bionic arm. You need precise aim to be able to swing and pull yourself up to other platforms. This is the hallmark of these original side-scrolling games like this. The controls work ok for keyboard and mouse, but I know I am not alone when I say that the original experience is much better through using a controller. It would be awesome if there could be PC compatibility for a Nintendo Entertainment System controller.Positive, Negative AspectsPros•Awesome 8-bit soundtrack that is high action•Awesome main character model that has been updated from the original. The main character looks cooler than he did before•Enemy models are represented based on their colors by faction•It is fun to run-and-gun and shoot enemies that we need to kill for a purpose•Excellent objectives, goals and milestones to work towardsCons•Might not appeal to the current generation of gamers we currently have•Takes much time and patience since there is also one initial life without any continues in single-player•More variety of controller options would be a nice addition for Capcom to add eventually•Capcom, give us a remastered version of the 2008 more current generation version to go along with this oneOverall- 7/10     A good remake of a classic side-scrolling platformer that takes strategy, time and patience to master.Key1-3 = poor4-5 = ok6-7 = good8-10 = amazingDisclaimer     I have only played this game so far on my other account at the time of this review. That one was provided by Accidently Reviewed. The person who donated the game from Accidently Reviewed on my other account did not specify which Bionic Commando game it was, and to my surprise, it was this one that I already owned. I don't mind having another game copy though because it is nice to have separate save files.

												A good game with some jarringly stressful levels at the end, namely the upper swinging section in 11 where you have to be very precise and a slight mispress of the claw arm button, which your press only has to be off by a milisecond, means having to re-navigate the bottom section to get back up for another most likely unsuccessful try. Then you have the final albatros level. It just ♥♥♥♥ing sucks. The first part, your claw arm doesn't work half the time on some of the platforms in one section, an obvious game glitch, and the rest is just a pure stress test. If your doctor ever wants you to take a stress test, tell him no thanks, you have already played Bionic Commando Rearmed. The last albatros level is the worst level I have ever seen in a video game. It was so incredibly stressful and so bull-shi--y that I just got tired of it and gave up and uninstalled the game because I just stopped caring, never to be ♥♥♥♥ed with again. You get through three door tests that are stupid enough in their own right, then the next section has changing platforms and collapsing hook grapple points. I was laughing at how stupidly stressful it was and just quit and am done with this game. Such a shame, all that work for such a truly God awful last level.Everything is good, but it will take some getting used to for most people because it is a platformer without a jump button. The idea is that your bionic arm is so heavy that you can't jump but you can sure as hell use it to swing around the levels awkwardly and that is the whole thing that made Bionic Commando unique in the first place, since the original. Everything works fine and it is a challenging game so some things are going to be immensely stressful in the levels but it is do-able with practice. The challenge levels in particular are probably the hardest, most stressful things I have ever done in my life, Unfortunately a lot of the picky awful programming that forces you to have perfect timing in the challenge levels trickles over into the story missions. On the 10th challenge I had no idea how to swing up to do it until I checked a youtube video. Even after watching how it was done I still had no idea how to do it until I read some detailed comments under the video and even then I still pretty much did it by luck. I gave up after the second set of them. The third set of challenges just got too stressful. I have never in my life seen anything require you to be so incredibly precise. If you don't swing right even for a milisecond you fail. If you dont hit the button within the right milisecond you fail. There is quite literally zero margin of error in the challenges, but thankfully they are not required so I am just enjoying the story levels. The graphics are awesome, the music is superb and is the best part of the game, the weapons and enemies solid, the animations realistic, and the gameplay is smooth. The only real way the game could be improved is if the dumb overly picky swing section in 11 was fixed and the last level wasn't so nightmarishly bad.The combat is ♥♥♥♥ing stressful as well because there is no recovery time so one hit and you are sometimes bouncing around like a pinball into other hits and you can either be killed in no time or be easily bounced off a platform and fall a long, long way down and have to reclimb the level which absolutely sucks. If only your guy wasn't such a stiff heavy snail with incredibly picky claw arm swing controls then it would be less frustrating.6/10, nothing but pure stress at the end. Get the 2009 Bionic Commando instead. The swinging in it is not done very well (gee what a surprise!) but it is not too bad and the game is still enjoyable but very short. The claw arm idea instead of a jump button is a very neat idea but it really should stay in these games and not be adopted by any others. Catch it (the 2009 3D version) only on sale though for $5 or less because it is a very short game.

And am I prepared to be lynched for it?Yes, also yes.I actually played this years ago on the Xbox 360, and remembered having a lot of trouble acclimating to the controls. I thought for sure that I was just a dumb kid back then, and that I'd get it the second time as a big strong adult. I sucked at platforms back then, and retro inspired ones especially. Now I'm a Castlevania fan. Times have changed! And this is a universally praised platformer, held higher than it's 2008 fully 3D remake, and I loved that game to death. I have to give it another try. It couldn't be as awkward as I remember. It was just as awkward, and I'll attempt to somehow explain.Imagine you were playing Metroid. You move, you shoot, you hop on platforms, pits are instant death, and touching enemies boops ya away. Now remove jumping. Now have all movement controls mapped to combinations of directions on the left control stick and the B button.Not so hard, right? Now make sure almost none of that directional input is the direction you want to go. Going upwards is about the only thing you're getting into your muscle memory without a fight. Simple actions requires unintuitive commands, such as pressing down and B to pull yourself under a gap to the left or right, or pressing B with no directional input to swing to the left or the right. This might not sound like too much, but when levels are multiple tiers of platforms full of enemies and death pits, it can be really frustrating to try and pull off multiple different kinds of obtuse commands and keep it all straight in your head. No one move you pull off is particularly complicated or outlandish, it just defies muscle memory with it's obtuse commands.So when everything is built around this bizarre 45 degree angle flat plain traversal, what am I to do when the first boss required me to interacting with something that was an inch off the ground? Yep. That's what did me in. That was what made me quit. A slightly raised barrel convinced me to refund Woolies Sacred Cow and then come to ♥♥♥♥♥ about how it's totes overrated yo.Seriously though, if you can somehow acclimate to these controls, I can actually see this being quite fun, so if they don't turn out to be a barrier for you, please disregard this entire review and enjoy your game, you lucky Mutant.

												I want to like this game, I really do. I'm just not feelin it.I remember the original bionic commando in all it's glory back in the NES days.This certainly tries to recapture that glory and maybe for some people it will be enough.For me it's just not there.For starters the controls are horrible. Unresponsive and crude are the best adjectives I can give for it. For one thing they can't even be bothered to use a readable font when instructing you. Press the "i" button... I pressed the i button, I pressed every button on the dam keyboard until I realized what they wanted was the j button. Do you know how much "j" looks like "i" ? well it shouldn't unless you use a terrible font.But suffer through the tutorial and you can get to a point where the controls are playable. Not fun per say, but sort of usable and I was able to beat all the tutorial "challenges".On to the game itself. I realize you don't typically play a platformer for a storyline. But wow, this is bad. It's so bad I would prefer they not have put one in at all. One page splash screens to launch each mission would have been preferable. Instead you get treated to page after page of back and forth dialogue that amounts to a meaningless pile of drivel peppered with cliche threats and taunts.If you can't be bothered to make a story decent then at least keep it short and relevent towards moving you from one mission to another. Don't give me long winded conversations about nothing interesting. Even the almost valid enemy coversations (that you hack into for hints about how to beat bosses) is dripping with cheese in the worst ways.I digress... gameplay. It feels like it's trying to be bionic commando but the entire game just feels... slow. Bullets fly by like butterflies that you could just reach out and swat if you wanted to. Movement is clunky and the entire game is like swimming in butter.I pushed on, treating it more like a puzzle game than a shooter. Though the minimalist puzzle mechanics seem to only be there to funnel you into more shootouts.There's a myriad of enemy troops but they all come accross as lazy and are beaten with essentially the same tactics. Level designs are short and feel meaningles. Boss fights were simplistic exagerations of the basic mechanics that only really become difficult when the controls don't respond in the way you want them to (which is frequent...).  Conceptually they were too easy to beat, but then the controls cheat you out of what you are trying to do and you get to start over. In the end boss fights felt unsatisfying.Beyond the main gameplay there's two other modes you get shoved into:1. hacking. at first these are frustrating, you weren't told what the controls are and trial and error will make you fail them (setting off alarms). once you do figure out the controls they are so simple to get through you wonder why they bothered, its just a waste of time. Spin cube, throw ball, spin cube, throw ball. I'm bored...2. top down shoot outs (between missions). On the world map when your helicopter flys over a convoy, she parks and lets you out to go walking around shooting things... Why? There's no logic to these stops, we could have flown past them or around them or.... Sadly these sections (as much as they don't make sense to the overal plot) are actually slightly more fun gameplay wise than the actual platforming game. The controls function without too much slippage and you actually get to use your bionic arm against enemies (even if its only to knock them back ~ where as in the main game your arm does nothing to them). Not that I'd want to play an entire game of this, they are once again too easy and not all that interesting.And that's where I am. I beat the tutorials, I played a few missions, I did some hacking and fought some convoys when my pilot decided to land between missions. But... meh. Overall I was bored. I took a break to get a drink and realized I had zero motivation to bother getting back into the game.I wanted to like this and for those who really need to scratch the nostalgia itch maybe it's on OK game. But it's just not cutting it for me. I'm bored and the controls suck really bad.

												So many painful, horrible, awful decisions were made with this game.  Was there a real reason to use the PhsyX engine?  No.  Was there a reason for the terrible default keybindings?  Nope.  Was there a reason I am not allowed to shoot in any other direction than forward?  No!  Even with its issues, Bionic Commando (the 3D PC game) was actually a better game than this.  If you like games in the "forward shooting only" genre, then Broforce is a WAY better game, infinitely more satisfying, hilarious at times, and quite fun.  This game, however, needed a LOT more playtesting and polish before distributing it to the world.  Developers can learn this lesson:  I get they were trying to be relatively faithful to the original, but keep in mind those games were limited in what they could do because the hardware was limited.  Repeating janky controls from the original doesn't help matters in any way.  Buyer beware!  This game probably won't work on your hardware without modifications.  Namely you will have to hunt down the legacy PhysX engine, switch the game's executable to Windows 7 compatibility mode, and probably restart Steam like I did to get it to start without crashing.  This game wasn't received well by critics and now I know why.  It's an ill-conceived PC game - at best - and it hasn't aged well in the few years it has been out.

												I wanted to like this game but it is killed by the same crappy control scheme that the original NES version was infamous for. Back in those NES glory days, we kids never questioned why a bionic commando would be unable to jump or climb over an obstacle. Now, though, it’s stupid and frustrating.Many positive reviews celebrate this as being a “hard” game, but all of its difficulty stems from the crappy controls. I knew exactly what I had to do and it wasn’t very complicated, but the controls are so unresponsive it became impossibly hard. Then I thought about how, if I did manage to make it into the secret area, I would have to navigate back out the way I came and survive through the rest of the level and the boss fight. If I ran out of lives before that, I’d have to do the entire level all over again. Who thinks that’s fun?This game could have been great if they had retooled the grappling system and the level designs. Instead they essentially lifted everything straight from the NES original aside from the graphics. If they weren’t going to update the controls, they should have at least given infinite lives & checkpoints inside levels since the gameplay boils down to tons of trial, error & luck. I bought this during a Steam sale and I regret the purchase. My advice is to get an emulated version of the original NES version. It will give you almost the same experience.

Bionic Commando: Rearmed is basically terrible.Grappling hooks are insanely awesome in gaming culture.  They're a major staple of the Zelda franchise, for example.  The Bionic Commando: Rearmed game showed some promise being one of the few 2D games I'd be excited to play that had a grappling hook mechanic.  Unfortunately, that mechanic was not implemented in an intuitive way.Tell them about getting the game to even work.Yes, yes, I was getting to that.  The game doesn't work out-of-box.  It is missing the PhysX driver it requires.  It comes bundled with PhysX as part of the install, but it doesn't install the correct version.  You require this legacy driver: http://www.nvidia.com/object/physx-9.13.0604-legacy-driver.html  (Thanks, support forums!)  That thankfully won't replace your latest PhysX driver, but it's a hoop you have to jump through just to get the game to load its initial agreement screen.  Then, you have to scroll through a lengthy contract with your arrow keys and finally agree to it before you can see the main menu.  At this point, I was already kind of upset with the game, but it had more issues going forward.Like the inability to target where you want the grappling hook to go?  Or the lack of a jump button?Yes, those two things exactly!  The controls were lacking a jump option, and the grappling mechanic was not as fun as it should have been.  I've seen free Flash-powered browser games from 2004 with more charm and elegance in their grappling mechanics than this game had.  I've seen better shooting mechanics in old arcade games from the late 80s and early 90s.  Compared to Contra or Metal Slug, I don't understand how anyone could recommend this game.The UI was nice, though.If this game has any nice points, it's the UI design.  Mind you, parts of the UI were non-functional, but most of it worked and looked very stylish.  It's a unique UI and worth the experience, I suppose, since the game was free.

To those less familiar with the original, let me take you on a magical journey - a journey through the world of 2-D platforming. Since before Mario jumped his first goomba, Jumping has been a thing in gaming. Jump up to reach the platforms, jump across gaps. In most games you even get some kind of gimmick, like shooting in Megaman, or your whip in Castlevania. But after some time, jumping and shooting and such was getting very much mainstream. It didn't make a memorable game by itself anymore. So, Capcom, fueled by the successes of Megaman and Street Fighter, made a move that only the geniuses that  they were at the time could have pulled off.They removed jumping. Yep. Just took jumping out of a platformer. Just *shoop* Don't need you today jumping. See ya in the next Megaman. I can just imagine the reaction in the meetings:"Why?! Why by all that is holy would you remove the most basic element of an action-adventure platformer?!"I'll tell you why. To put in something much better.Rather that go with the overused jumping mechaincs, they gave you a grapling hook arm, and introduced a swing mechanic. Yes. SWINGING. It may be a little awkward and counterintuitive at first. You may fall into that first pit a dozen times. But keep going, and it suddenly clicks, and you turn into a greenish blur swing through the stages with skill to put Tarzan to shame.Were the folks at Capcom insane?    Yes. Were they geniuses?    Also yes.But that's not all. Though the story is linear, it gives you an overworld map with a Metriodvania style of exploration. Add to this already unique game one of the best original soundtracks 8-bit games have ever seen, and you got yourself one of the greatest gems the NES has ever offered us.But that's the NES game. Here we have the "Rearmed" version. And, long story short, it is incredible.Take all of those things that made the original great, and add spectacular 2.5-D graphics, additional mechanics to excite the modern gamer, enhanced soundtrack that still remains true to the original, fun cutscene artwork, a co-op mode, and enough nostalgia tripping to bring a happy tear to the every eye in the collective community of NES gamers, and you get one great game.Now to be fair, there are a couple of con's here.To maintain the nostalgia factor, they kept the threadbare story from the original, updating it slightly to flow a little more smoothly. So if you're into in-depth storyline games, you're not gonna get much here. It's pretty cut-and-dry. Kill badguys, get cool stuff, kill more badguys, save the day.And, like I mentioned above, the swinging takes some getting used to. You have to be pretty precise at some points, so you'll need some patience to develop the skill. Probably not the best thing for a casual gamer.But all in all, this is a wonderful reboot.The great thing is that this 2008 release was obviously meant to build excitement and hype for the 2009 realease of a full 3-D Bionic Commando game. So, we basically got a great game with new life breathed into it for the sake of advertising.

												Pretty well done remake of the NES classic. The boss fights (if you can even call them that) from the old version have been almost totally redone, and are much more satisfying. They are actually unique boss fights, rather than just swarms of enemies coming at you while you try to destroy a reactor.The remixed and new music, as well as the sound effects, sound good while keeping a hint of their retro roots. Similar to the music, the levels maintain a nice balance of retro throwbacks and new creations deisgned to really test your ability with the bionic arm. The difficulty of the platforming ramps up nicely, and gets kind of rough at some end parts. There are unlockable challenge rooms as well, that will teach you more advanced mechanics, and improve your skills.The weapons from the original have all been reworked and are more varied, with certain weapons performing better against certain foes, or in certain situations. The top down levels when you encounter an enemy on the map have been improved as well, but they are so easy and short that they almost feel more like an inconvenience than an addition to the gameplay.The "puzzles" you must solve when you hack into enemy communications are also pretty pointless. 95% of the time, there is only one move you can make per turn that won't result in instant failure. This makes them almost solve themselves, and ensures you are not required to actually think for yourself at all.That being said, in regards to the communication rooms, you are no longer required to have the correct color radio selected to be able to communicate without just getting static. The complaints are minor, and if you enjoyed the original this is kind of a no brainer.

It didn't make a memorable game by itself anymore. So, Capcom, fueled by the successes of Megaman and Street Fighter, made a move that only the geniuses that  they were at the time could have pulled off.They removed jumping. Yep. Just took jumping out of a platformer. Just *shoop* Don't need you today jumping. See ya in the next Megaman. I can just imagine the reaction in the meetings:"Why?! Why by all that is holy would you remove the most basic element of an action-adventure platformer?!"I'll tell you why. To put in something much better.Rather that go with the overused jumping mechaincs, they gave you a grapling hook arm, and introduced a swing mechanic. Yes. SWINGING. It may be a little awkward and counterintuitive at first. You may fall into that first pit a dozen times. But keep going, and it suddenly clicks, and you turn into a greenish blur swing through the stages with skill to put Tarzan to shame.Were the folks at Capcom insane?    Yes. Were they geniuses?    Also yes.But that's not all. Though the story is linear, it gives you an overworld map with a Metriodvania style of exploration. Add to this already unique game one of the best original soundtracks 8-bit games have ever seen, and you got yourself one of the greatest gems the NES has ever offered us.But that's the NES game. Here we have the "Rearmed" version. And, long story short, it is incredible.Take all of those things that made the original great, and add spectacular 2.5-D graphics, additional mechanics to excite the modern gamer, enhanced soundtrack that still remains true to the original, fun cutscene artwork, a co-op mode, and enough nostalgia tripping to bring a happy tear to the every eye in the collective community of NES gamers, and you get one great game.Now to be fair, there are a couple of con's here.To maintain the nostalgia factor, they kept the threadbare story from the original, updating it slightly to flow a little more smoothly. So if you're into in-depth storyline games, you're not gonna get much here. It's pretty cut-and-dry. Kill badguys, get cool stuff, kill more badguys, save the day.And, like I mentioned above, the swinging takes some getting used to. You have to be pretty precise at some points, so you'll need some patience to develop the skill. Probably not the best thing for a casual gamer.But all in all, this is a wonderful reboot.The great thing is that this 2008 release was obviously meant to build excitement and hype for the 2009 realease of a full 3-D Bionic Commando game. So, we basically got a great game with new life breathed into it for the sake of advertising.

												Having never played the original, I really wanted to try out the remake, especially after playing the demo on the PS3 and falling in love with the title song. The game is not complicated, weapons are varied and have different uses, and the graphics are colorful and varient. Only gripes I may have are there's no online coop or multiplayer, sometimes the background scenery can distract you and make you think it's part of the level, and some pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t enemy placements. Overall, I'll recommend the game, especially on a sale (Capcom sale currently going on with $1.99. It's a steal). The people who complain about "Theres no jjump!!1" have trouble getting the idea of different control schemes in their head. I pity them, because they are missing an amazing game, with an even more amazing soundtrack.

												This game is an amazing and loving recreation of the original Bionic Commando for NES. A unique platformer that stands the test of time due to it's strong mechanics. A strong single player story with memorable levels and a catch soundtrack make this a solid purchase. Secrets abound and a new co-op mode add replayability and make it a steal.
